articles.headline: Products and Competition Stretch Market for ‘Athleisure’ Clothing
articles.snippet: Seemingly every clothing brand and retailer wants in on clothing made both for exercise and for everyday wear, but the market is becoming crowded.
articles.abstract: Seemingly every clothing brand and retailer wants in on clothing made both for exercise and for everyday wear, but the market is becoming crowded.
articles.lead_paragraph: The beams are still bare in Yogasmoga’s first Manhattan store, juice bar and fitness studio. But Rishi Bali raves that he is building the next Lululemon — only better.

articles.headline: The Race Is On to Control Artificial Intelligence, and Tech’s Future
articles.snippet: Amazon, Google, IBM and Microsoft are using high salaries and games pitting humans against computers to try to claim the standard on which all companies will build their A.I. technology.
articles.abstract: Amazon, Google, IBM and Microsoft are using high salaries and games pitting humans against computers to try to claim the standard on which all companies will build their A.I. technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The resounding win by a Google artificial intelligence program over a champion in the complex board game Go this month was a statement — not so much to professional game players as to Google’s competitors.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Tribune Chief Discusses Transforming a Mature Media Company
articles.snippet: Peter Liguori talked about the transformation of Tribune and the broader media industry during a recent interview in his New York office.
articles.abstract: Peter Liguori talked about the transformation of Tribune and the broader media industry during a recent interview in his New York office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Liguori, the longtime television executive, was appointed the new chief executive of the Tribune Company in 2013, just two and a half weeks after the newspaper and TV company emerged from an agonizing four-year bankruptcy process.

articles.headline: Democrats See Gains as Donald Trump Targets a Wife
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s nasty skirmish with Ted Cruz about Mr. Cruz’s wife, Heidi, has played into a Democratic strategy to defeat Mr. Trump in November: to portray him as an unabashed sexist.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s nasty skirmish with Ted Cruz about Mr. Cruz’s wife, Heidi, has played into a Democratic strategy to defeat Mr. Trump in November: to portray him as an unabashed sexist.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz may have urged Donald J. Trump to leave his wife, Heidi, “the hell alone,” but there is one group that is quietly hoping Mr. Trump’s attacks on his rival’s spouse and other women will continue indefinitely: Democrats.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Belgium Fears Nuclear Plants Are Vulnerable
articles.snippet: Belgian authorities fear that Islamic State militants may try to attack, infiltrate or sabotage nuclear plants or obtain nuclear or radioactive material.
articles.abstract: Belgian authorities fear that Islamic State militants may try to attack, infiltrate or sabotage nuclear plants or obtain nuclear or radioactive material.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As a dragnet aimed at Islamic State operatives spiraled across Brussels and into at least five European countries on Friday, the authorities were also focusing on a narrower but increasingly alarming threat: the vulnerability of Belgium’s nuclear installations.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Milan Schreuer

articles.headline: Fighting a Cage Match to Turn UFC Into a National Phenomenon
articles.snippet: Two brothers have worked to bring what some critics have derided as “human cage fighting” into the lucrative mainstream of spectator sports.
articles.abstract: Two brothers have worked to bring what some critics have derided as “human cage fighting” into the lucrative mainstream of spectator sports.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a while since Frank and Lorenzo Fertitta tried to choke each other into submission. The brothers took private jujitsu lessons in the early 2000s, and at the end of each they were given the chance to try new moves in a dojo in Las Vegas. But you reach a certain age (Frank is now 54, Lorenzo is 47) and turn up in Forbes (which estimates each brother is worth $1.6 billion), and brawling starts to seem like a bad idea.

articles.headline: Schools Nationwide Still Grapple With Lead in Water
articles.snippet: The Flint, Mich., crisis has cast attention on the issue, but in schools from Jersey City, N.J., to Los Angeles, problems have dragged on for years.
articles.abstract: The Flint, Mich., crisis has cast attention on the issue, but in schools from Jersey City, N.J., to Los Angeles, problems have dragged on for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Anxious parents may wonder how a major school system like Newark’s could overlook lead in the drinking water of 30 schools and 17,000 students. The answer: It was easy. They had to look only a few miles away, at the century-old classrooms of the schools here, across the Hackensack River.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines, Patrick McGeehan and John Schwartz

articles.headline: In Brussels Bombing Plot, a Trail of Dots Not Connected
articles.snippet: Only on the morning of the attacks did chemical odors and other strange hints come together to form a clear picture of what had been happening at the apartment used as a bomb-making workshop.
articles.abstract: Only on the morning of the attacks did chemical odors and other strange hints come together to form a clear picture of what had been happening at the apartment used as a bomb-making workshop.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The stench of chemicals emanating from the sixth-floor apartment made the owner of the building gag. Other odd happenings at the mostly empty housing block in northern Brussels prompted an anxious resident in the area to alert the police. A taxi driver who picked up three young men at the block smelled a noxious odor leaking from their curiously heavy luggage as he drove them to Brussels Airport.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: In Donald Trump’s Worldview, America Comes First, and Everybody Else Pays
articles.snippet: In a 100-minute interview, Mr. Trump said he might halt purchases of oil from Arab allies like Saudi Arabia unless they commit greater resources to fighting the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: In a 100-minute interview, Mr. Trump said he might halt purchases of oil from Arab allies like Saudi Arabia unless they commit greater resources to fighting the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential front-runner, said that if elected, he might halt purchases of oil from Saudi Arabia and other Arab allies unless they commit ground troops to the fight against the Islamic State or “substantially reimburse” the United States for combating the militant group, which threatens their stability.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Seizes 3 States, Sweeping Democratic Contests
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in Washington, Alaska and Hawaii, which held nominating contests on Saturday.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in Washington, Alaska and Hawaii, which held nominating contests on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders routed Hillary Clinton in all three Democratic presidential contests on Saturday, infusing his underdog campaign with critical momentum and bolstering his argument that the race for the nomination is not a foregone conclusion.

articles.headline: Merrick Garland Is a Deft Navigator of Washington’s Legal Circles
articles.snippet: Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, has advanced as a centrist in a city where ambition is often rewarded when accompanied by partisan loyalty.
articles.abstract: Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, has advanced as a centrist in a city where ambition is often rewarded when accompanied by partisan loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twice a day, for breakfast and lunch, Benjamin R. Civiletti, attorney general to President Jimmy Carter, invited his seven special assistants — mostly young graduates of the nation’s most prestigious law schools — to his private dining room at the Justice Department for casual conversation or friendly debate.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Matt Apuzzo and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: A Supreme Court Pioneer, Now Making Her Mark on Video Games
articles.snippet: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor said she had never played video games until a few years ago. But now she is using them to teach students valuable civics lessons.
articles.abstract: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor said she had never played video games until a few years ago. But now she is using them to teach students valuable civics lessons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, who turned 86 on Saturday, has many achievements to her name, including serving as a state senator in Arizona and becoming the first woman appointed to the Supreme Court, where she served for almost a quarter-century.

articles.headline: The Trade Deficit Isn’t a Scorecard, and Cutting It Won’t Make America Great Again
articles.snippet: Trying to eliminate the trade deficit could mean giving up levers of power that allow the U.S. to get its way in international politics.
articles.abstract: Trying to eliminate the trade deficit could mean giving up levers of power that allow the U.S. to get its way in international politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump believes that a half-trillion-dollar trade deficit with the rest of the world makes the United States a loser and countries with trade surpluses like China and Mexico winners.

articles.headline: Blast at a Crowded Park in Lahore, Pakistan, Kills Dozens
articles.snippet: The blast, which appeared to be caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at a park popular with families, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300.
articles.abstract: The blast, which appeared to be caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at a park popular with families, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suicide bomber set off a powerful blast close to a children’s swing set in a public park on Sunday evening in the eastern city of Lahore, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300, rescue workers and officials said.

articles.headline: American Tech Giants Face Fight in Europe Over Encrypted Data
articles.snippet: As Apple battles the F.B.I. over “unlocking” an iPhone, European governments are pushing for greater access to people’s digital lives.
articles.abstract: As Apple battles the F.B.I. over “unlocking” an iPhone, European governments are pushing for greater access to people’s digital lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Silicon Valley’s battle over encryption is heading to Europe.

articles.headline: A Castro Met a Free Press, and the World Watched It Live
articles.snippet: As President Raúl Castro of Cuba stammered over questions from the news media, it was a reminder of the signs of regression concerning President Obama and the press back home.
articles.abstract: As President Raúl Castro of Cuba stammered over questions from the news media, it was a reminder of the signs of regression concerning President Obama and the press back home.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thing about dictators is they don’t have to answer any stinking questions from the press. We call it undemocratic; they call it job security.

articles.headline: Who Will Become a Terrorist? Research Yields Few Clues
articles.snippet: The question of what turns people toward violence — and whether they can be steered away from it — has bedeviled governments around the world for generations.
articles.abstract: The question of what turns people toward violence — and whether they can be steered away from it — has bedeviled governments around the world for generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The brothers who carried out suicide bombings in Brussels last week had long, violent criminal records and had been regarded internationally as potential terrorists. But in San Bernardino, Calif., last year, one of the attackers was a county health inspector who lived a life of apparent suburban normality.

articles.headline: Ethereum, a Virtual Currency, Enables Transactions That Rival Bitcoin’s
articles.snippet: In addition to virtual currency, Ethereum also provides a way to create online markets and programmable transactions known as smart contracts.
articles.abstract: In addition to virtual currency, Ethereum also provides a way to create online markets and programmable transactions known as smart contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new virtual gold rush is underway.

articles.headline: Charter’s $67 Billion Cable Merger Hinges on the Cord Cutters
articles.snippet: Charter Communications is poised to gain F.C.C. approval to join with Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, and streaming looms large in the deal.
articles.abstract: Charter Communications is poised to gain F.C.C. approval to join with Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, and streaming looms large in the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charter Communications is within striking distance of finally capturing its prize.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: How the G.O.P. Elite Lost Its Voters to Donald Trump
articles.snippet: The party establishment abandoned its most faithful voters, blue-collar workers who faced economic pain while donors, lawmakers and lobbyists prospered.
articles.abstract: The party establishment abandoned its most faithful voters, blue-collar workers who faced economic pain while donors, lawmakers and lobbyists prospered.
articles.lead_paragraph: The manufacturing executives had gathered in an Atlanta conference room last year to honor their senior United States senator, Johnny Isakson, for his tireless efforts on their behalf in Washington. But as the luncheon wound down, Mr. Isakson found himself facing a man from Coweta County. The man, Burl Finkelstein, said trade policies with Mexico and China were strangling the family-owned kitchen-parts company he helped manage, and imperiling the jobs it provided. Mr. Isakson politely brushed him off, Mr. Finkelstein recalled, as he had many times before.

articles.headline: Violence Surges in Chicago Even as Policing Debate Rages On
articles.snippet: Murders and shootings have risen sharply this year, and the increase could hardly have come at a more difficult time.
articles.abstract: Murders and shootings have risen sharply this year, and the increase could hardly have come at a more difficult time.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Late at night this month, the pastor’s phone beeped with a text message from an anguished parishioner. Andre Taylor, the church member’s great-nephew, had been shot and killed.
